M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and Mass. Gen. Laws c. 215, § 6, as the original custody and parenting time order was issued by this Court.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and Mass. Gen. Laws c. 215, § 6, as the original custody and parenting time order was issued by this Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and Mass. Gen. Laws c. 215, § 6, as the original custody and parenting time order was issued by this Court.

Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” since entry of the prior judgment and that the proposed modification is in the “best interests of the child”. See M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011); Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014).
Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011).case_name: Beres v. Board of Registration of Chiropractors
Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the authority of a single justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court under G.L. c. 211, § 4A to transfer a timely‑filed professional licensing review action from the Superior Court to the SJC. It does not address custody, parenting time, modification standards, or the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ / ‘best interests of the child’ test under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Citing this case for that family‑law modification standard is inaccurate and unsupported by the text of the decision.
Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011).relevant_excerpt: Because G. L. c. 211, § 4A, permits a single justice of this court, in the sound exercise of his or her discretion, to transfer a case timely filed in another court to this court, we vacate the judgment of the single justice, and remand for consideration whether exercise of that discretion is appropriate in the circumstances of this case. As to that, we express no opinion.

Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” since entry of the prior judgment and that the proposed modification is in the “best interests of the child”. See M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Smith v. Smith, 459 Mass. 1012 (2011); Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014).
Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014).support_reasoning: This opinion (Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014)) is a criminal case about speedy trial rights under Mass. R. Crim. P. 36 and the law of restitution. It does not address family law, custody, parenting time, or modification standards, nor does it interpret M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 or c. 209C, § 20, or discuss a “material and substantial change in circumstances” or the “best interests of the child.” The citation is therefore inapposite for the proposition stated.
Myrick v. Maloney, 466 Mass. 727 (2014).relevant_excerpt: We address the question of restitution to clarify our case law following decisions of the United States Supreme Court in Southern Union Co. v. United States, 132 S. Ct. 2344 (2012), and Alleyne v. United States, 133 S. Ct. 2151 (2013). The defendant asserts that, pursuant to these cases, factual determinations relevant to a restitution order must be made by a jury beyond a reasonable doubt, rather than by the judge by a preponderance of the evidence. We agree with the Commonwealth that these cases are not at odds with our approach to restitution.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: The Court’s paramount consideration in matters of custody and parenting time is the best interests of the child. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (2006).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly situates the custody analysis within the long-established Massachusetts rule that custody determinations turn on the best interests of the child and describes that standard as the paramount concern. It then applies that standard as the governing framework for evaluating the custody award in this case. This directly supports the proposition that the court’s paramount consideration in custody and parenting time matters is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: The Court’s paramount consideration in matters of custody and parenting time is the best interests of the child. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the removal analysis in terms of the children’s best interests and repeatedly describes the judge’s and the court’s task as determining what is in the children’s best interests. While this is in the specific context of removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint custody situation, the court makes clear that the governing standard is the best interests of the child, consistent with the broader custody jurisprudence cited in Custody of Kali.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal… was not in the best interests of the children….”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts appellate precedent recognizes that relocation and changes in a parent’s residence are quintessential examples of material changes warranting review. See Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); Mason v. Coleman, supra; Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 772 (2006).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal does not characterize relocation or a change in a parent’s residence as, in itself, a quintessential or sufficient ‘material and substantial change’ warranting review. To the contrary, the court holds that a request for relocation is distinct from a request to modify custody and that a modification must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move. Thus, citing Rosenthal for the broad proposition that relocation itself is a paradigmatic material change misstates its holding.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 772 (2006)
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate precedent recognizes that relocation and changes in a parent’s residence are quintessential examples of material changes warranting review. See Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); Mason v. Coleman, supra; Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 772 (2006).
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Wakefield is a removal/relocation case applying the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best-interests tests, but it does not address modification standards or characterize relocation or residential changes as a ‘quintessential’ example of a material change warranting review. The opinion assumes jurisdiction over the removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and analyzes whether relocation should be allowed, not whether a proposed move constitutes a material change justifying reopening custody or parenting orders. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific material-change proposition cited.
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if at suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” The purpose of the statute is to preserve the rights of the noncustodial parent and the child to maintain and develop their familial relationships, while balancing those rights with the right of the custodial parent to seek a better life for himself or herself in another State or country.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Courts have consistently held that when a parenting plan becomes unworkable due to logistical impracticability or increased hardship on the child, modification is appropriate. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case, not a parenting-plan-modification case based on logistical impracticability or hardship on the child. The opinion discusses standards for allowing a custodial parent to relocate children out of the Commonwealth (the “real advantage” test and best interests analysis), but it does not address modification of an existing parenting plan because it became unworkable or too burdensome. Thus, citing Yannas for a general rule about modification due to logistical impracticability or increased hardship on the child overstates its holding and mischaracterizes its focus.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent…”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Courts have consistently held that when a parenting plan becomes unworkable due to logistical impracticability or increased hardship on the child, modification is appropriate. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: Hale addresses when a custodial parent may remove children from the Commonwealth and sets out best‑interest factors, focusing on the welfare of the custodial parent and alternative visitation arrangements. It does not discuss modification of an existing parenting plan because it has become logistically unworkable or imposes increased hardship on the child; the issue is initial/ongoing permission to relocate under G.L. c. 208, § 30. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification of an unworkable parenting plan.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We consider that factor [difficulty of visitation] not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account. … We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

Custody of Vaughan, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The maintenance of a stable environment, consistent schooling, and regular access to community and extracurricular activities forms the cornerstone of the “best interests” analysis. See Custody of Vaughan, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Chin v. Merriot, 470 Mass. 527 (2015).
Custody of Vaughan, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the requirement that courts make explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child when determining best interests. While the court notes that the child is doing well in school and that the father is involved in his activities, it does not elevate ‘stable environment, consistent schooling, and regular access to community and extracurricular activities’ to the cornerstone of the best-interests analysis. Instead, the central doctrinal emphasis is on domestic violence and its impact, not on stability/schooling/extracurriculars as the primary determinant.
Custody of Vaughan, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Chin v. Merriot, 470 Mass. 527 (2015).proposition: The maintenance of a stable environment, consistent schooling, and regular access to community and extracurricular activities forms the cornerstone of the “best interests” analysis. See Custody of Vaughan, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Chin v. Merriot, 470 Mass. 527 (2015).
Chin v. Merriot, 470 Mass. 527 (2015).support_reasoning: Chin v. Merriot is an alimony-modification and statutory-interpretation case about the prospective application of the Alimony Reform Act’s retirement and cohabitation provisions. It does not address child custody, “best interests of the child,” or factors such as stable environment, schooling, or access to community/extracurricular activities. The opinion therefore does not provide authority for the claimed best-interests proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that purpose.
Chin v. Merriot, 470 Mass. 527 (2015).relevant_excerpt: The question we confront in this case is whether modification of an obligation to pay periodic or general term alimony that is contained in a merged provision of a divorce judgment is governed by the alimony reform act, where the act became effective after the date of entry of the judgment. We conclude that, with respect to the alimony obligation at issue here, both the retirement provision and the cohabitation provision apply prospectively, and therefore afford no basis upon which to terminate the alimony order.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Forcing Emily to endure long commutes multiple times per week for overnight visitation conflicts with the statutory aims of stability, developmental continuity, and emotional security contemplated by M.G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related authority.
